title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: tidycensuskr package provides easy access South Korean census socioeconomic statistics, along corresponding geospatial boundary data. package, R users can query visualize population, housing, economy, tax, mortality data linked administrative districts. Load package:
code: library(tidycensuskr)

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: South Korean census data organized three levels administrative divisions: Metropolitan cities treated provinces. Jeju-, Gangwon-, Jeollabuk-special self-governing status Korean law. Si: Cities (urban administrative units) Gun: Counties (rural areas, typically <50,000 population) Gu metropolitan cities autonomous districts Gu 11 large cities, 2025 (.e., Suwon-si, Seongnam-si, Anyang-si, Goyang-si, Ansan-si, Yongin-si, Cheongju-si, Cheonan-si, Pohang-si, Changwon-si, Jeonju-si), administraitve districts Eup: Towns (urban, >20,000 population, within county) Myeon: Townships (rural, <20,000 population, within county) Dong: Neighborhoods (smallest units within cities districts)

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: table provides rough comparison administrative divisions across South Korea, United States, European Union, United Kingdom (England). correspondence exact, can helpful understand approximate levels working census regional data.  administrative boundaries coding systems can vary across years data sources, tidycensuskr harmonizes codes allow consistent integration statistics. Currently, 2020 data 250 Si-Gun-Gu 17 Si-.
code: adm2_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020) print(length(unique(adm2_2020$adm2_code))) #> [1] 250

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: package provides census survey data : - function anycensus() querying subsets - built-dataset censuskor long format

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: function anycensus() returns tidy tibble columns : year: year dataset adm1, adm1_code: Si-(province) level administrative unit name corresponding code adm2, adm2_code: Si-Gun-Gu (district) level administrative unit name corresponding code Columns containing values added wide form. column adm2_code links census data directly boundary files retrieved load_districts(). function can also aggregate values higher administrative units. specifying level = "adm1" providing aggregation function, obtain province-level (adm1) results summarize across districts.
code: df_2020 <- anycensus(year = 2020,                       type = "mortality",                      level = "adm2") head(df_2020) #> # A tibble: 6 × 9 #>    year adm1              adm1_code adm2  adm2_code type  `all causes_total_p1p` #>   <int> <chr>                 <dbl> <chr>     <dbl> <chr>                  <dbl> #> 1  2020 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheo…     33040 mort…                   312. #> 2  2020 Chungcheongnam-do        34 Cheo…     34010 mort…                   321. #> 3  2020 Gyeongsangbuk-do         37 Poha…     37010 mort…                   318. #> 4  2020 Gyeongsangnam-do         38 Chan…     38110 mort…                   323. #> 5  2020 Jeollabuk-do             35 Jeon…     35010 mort…                   283. #> 6  2020 Gyeongsangbuk-do         37 Ando…     37040 mort…                   353  #> # ℹ 2 more variables: `all causes_male_p1p` <dbl>, #> #   `all causes_female_p1p` <dbl> df_2020_sido <- anycensus(year = 2020,                            type = "mortality",                           level = "adm1",                           aggregator = sum,                           na.rm = TRUE) head(df_2020_sido) #> # A tibble: 6 × 7 #> # Groups:   year, type, adm1, adm1_code [6] #>    year type      adm1    adm1_code `all causes_total_p1p` `all causes_male_p1p` #>   <int> <chr>     <chr>       <dbl>                  <dbl>                 <dbl> #> 1  2020 mortality Busan          21                  5367.                 7327. #> 2  2020 mortality Chungc…        33                  5160.                 7037. #> 3  2020 mortality Chungc…        34                  5707.                 7646. #> 4  2020 mortality Daegu          22                  2486.                 3405. #> 5  2020 mortality Daejeon        25                  1529.                 1996  #> 6  2020 mortality Gangwo…        32                  6125.                 8382. #> # ℹ 1 more variable: `all causes_female_p1p` <dbl>

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: can access whole dataset directly using function data(censuskor) returns built-dataset long form. year: year dataset adm1, adm1_code: Si-(province) level administrative unit name corresponding code adm2, adm2_code: Si-Gun-Gu (district) level administrative unit name corresponding code type: Types census survey class1, class2: Classification variables providing breakdowns unit: Measurement unit value value: observed census value given combination year, region, category
code: data(censuskor) head(censuskor) #>   year              adm1 adm1_code        adm2 adm2_code       type #> 1 2010 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33010 population #> 2 2010 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33010 population #> 3 2010 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33010 population #> 4 2020 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33040        tax #> 5 2020 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33040        tax #> 6 2015 Chungcheongbuk-do        33 Cheongju-si     33040 population #>           class1  class2        unit  value #> 1 all households   total     persons 646939 #> 2 all households    male     persons 318355 #> 3 all households  female     persons 328584 #> 4         income general million KRW 524478 #> 5         income   labor million KRW 598560 #> 6 all households   total     persons 797099

title: Working with tidycensuskr
text: Since anycensus() returns tidy data, visualization ggplot2 straightforward.
code: ggplot(df_2020, aes(x = `all causes_male_p1p`, y = `all causes_female_p1p`)) +   geom_point() +   labs(     x = "Male mortality (per 100,000 population)",     y = "Female mortality (per 100,000 population)",     title = "Male vs. Female Age-standardized Mortality Rates in South Korea (2020)"   ) +   theme_minimal(base_size = 10)

previous_headings: Example 1: Population change in the Gyeongsangnam-do region
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: Load 2010 2020 census population data. Merge 2020 district boundaries. Calculate population change (change = 2020 − 2010). Subset Gyeongsangnam-, Busan, Ulsan. Create diverging choropleth map show population increase/decrease, inset map Korea highlighting region.

previous_headings: Example 1: Population change in the Gyeongsangnam-do region
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
code: # Load 2020 boundaries sf_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020) # Load census population data for 2010 and 2020 df_2010_pop <- anycensus(year = 2010,                           codes = c("Gyeongsangnam-do", "Busan", "Ulsan"),                           type = "population") df_2020_pop <- anycensus(year = 2020,                           codes = c("Gyeongsangnam-do", "Busan", "Ulsan"),                           type = "population")  # Merge with spatial data and compute population change sf_target <- sf_2020 |>   inner_join(df_2010_pop, by = "adm2_code") |>   inner_join(df_2020_pop, by = "adm2_code") |>   mutate(change = `all households_total_prs.y` - `all households_total_prs.x`)

previous_headings: Example 1: Population change in the Gyeongsangnam-do region
what: A choropleth map with an inset map
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: Gyeongsangnam-region, large metropolitan cities Busan Ulsan show population decline, surrounding suburban areas demonstrate notable population gains. Rural areas western part province exhibit relatively stable population trends.
code: # Choropleth map for population change map <- ggplot(sf_target) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = change), color = "gray80", size = 0.1) +   labs(title = "Population change between 2010 and 2020") +   scale_fill_gradient2(     low = "#2C7BB6", mid = "white", high = "#D7191C",     midpoint = 0,     name = "Change"   ) +   theme_void() +   annotation_scale(location = "tr", width_hint = 0.25, text_cex = 0.7, line_width = 0.7)  # National boundary (union of all districts) sf_korea_boundary <- sf_2020 |>   summarise(geometry = st_union(geometry))  # Target region boundary (union of selected provinces/cities) sf_target_boundary <- sf_target |>   summarise(geometry = st_union(geometry))  # Inset map: whole Korea + highlighted target region korea_inset <- ggplot() +   geom_sf(data = sf_korea_boundary, fill = "grey90", color = "grey90") +   geom_sf(data = sf_target_boundary, fill = "grey30", color = "grey30") +   theme_void()  # Combine main map and inset cowplot::ggdraw() +   cowplot::draw_plot(map) +   cowplot::draw_plot(korea_inset, x = 0.7, y = 0.05, width = 0.25, height = 0.25) +   draw_grob(grid::rectGrob(gp = gpar(col = "black", fill = NA, lwd = 0.6)),             x = 0.7, y = 0.05, width = 0.25, height = 0.25)

previous_headings: Example 2: Bivariate mapping of population vs. tax
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: Load 2020 population tax datasets. tax data available Gu level large cities, aggregate district-level (adm2_code) data 4-digit prefix level. Merge population tax data. Use biscale::bi_class() create 3×3 bivariate classification population (x) vs. tax (y). Draw bivariate choropleth map custom legend.

previous_headings: Example 2: Bivariate mapping of population vs. tax
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
code: # Load 2020 boundaries sf_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020) # Load census data df_2020_pop <- anycensus(year = 2020,                          type = "population") df_2020_tax <- anycensus(year = 2020,                          type = "tax")  # Merge population with boundaries sf_2020_pop <- sf_2020 |>   left_join(df_2020_pop, by = "adm2_code") |>   mutate(     adm2_code_chr = as.character(adm2_code),     adm2_prefix4  = substr(adm2_code_chr, 1, 4),     last_digit    = substr(adm2_code_chr, 5, 5)   )  # Aggregate smaller units (adm2_code ending not with 0) into 4-digit groups sf_union_needed <- sf_2020_pop |>   filter(last_digit != "0") |>   group_by(adm2_prefix4) |>   summarise(     across(where(is.numeric), ~ sum(.x, na.rm = TRUE)),     geometry = st_union(geometry),     .groups = "drop"   ) |>   mutate(adm2_code = as.numeric(paste0(adm2_prefix4, "0")))  # Combine aggregated units with existing "0"-ending districts sf_2020_unioned <- sf_2020_pop |>   filter(last_digit == "0") |>   bind_rows(sf_union_needed)  # Join with tax data sf_final <- sf_2020_unioned |>   left_join(df_2020_tax, by = "adm2_code")

previous_headings: Example 2: Bivariate mapping of population vs. tax
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: bivariate map highlights strong centrality Seoul Metropolitan Area. capital region southeastern manufacturing hubs exhibit high population high tax revenues. contrast, regions—Gangwon Gyeongbuk, apart metropolitan centers—fall low population–low tax category.
code: # Create 3x3 bivariate classes (population vs tax) bi_data <- bi_class(   sf_final,   x = `all households_total_prs`,   y = income_general_mkr,   style = "quantile",   dim = 3 )  # Bivariate legend legend <- bi_legend(   pal = "DkCyan", dim = 3,   xlab = "Low to High population",   ylab = "Low to High tax",   size = 7 )  # Mapping cowplot::ggdraw() +   cowplot::draw_plot(     ggplot() +       geom_sf(data = bi_data, aes(fill = bi_class), color = NA) +       bi_scale_fill(pal = "DkCyan", dim = 3, guide = "none") +       bi_theme() +       labs(title = "Population vs Tax (2020)") +       theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 10))   ) +   cowplot::draw_plot(legend, x = 0.7, y = 0.1, width = 0.3, height = 0.3)

previous_headings: Example 3: Sex ratio in Seoul Metropolitan Area
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: Load 2020 population data Seoul, Gyeonggi-, Incheon. Calculate sex ratio (male/female × 100). Show overall distribution grey background histogram. Overlay regional distributions (Seoul, Incheon, Gyeonggi-) color facets. Map sex ratio across districts, using diverging color scale centered 100 (balanced sex ratio).

previous_headings: Example 3: Sex ratio in Seoul Metropolitan Area
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
code: # Load population data for the Seoul Metropolitan Area (SMA) df_sma <- anycensus(   year  = 2020,   codes = c("Seoul", "Gyeonggi-do", "Incheon"),   type  = "population" )  # Calculate sex ratio (males per 100 females) df_sma <- df_sma |>   mutate(sex_ratio = `all households_male_prs` / `all households_female_prs` * 100)  # Extract overall distribution (all SMA combined) df_all <- df_sma |>   select(sex_ratio)

previous_headings: Example 3: Sex ratio in Seoul Metropolitan Area
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
code: ggplot() +   # Background: overall distribution across all SMA   geom_histogram(     data = df_all,     aes(x = sex_ratio, y = after_stat(density)),     bins = 20, fill = "grey80", color = NA, alpha = 1   ) +   # Regional distributions   geom_histogram(     data = df_sma,     aes(x = sex_ratio, y = after_stat(density), fill = adm1),     bins = 20, alpha = 0.7, color = NA, position = "identity"   ) +   facet_wrap(~ adm1, ncol = 3, scales = "free_y") +   scale_fill_manual(values = c(     "Seoul" = "darkorange",     "Incheon" = "purple",     "Gyeonggi-do" = "cyan4"   )) +   labs(     title = "Sex ratio distribution by region (SMA, 2020)",     x = "Sex ratio (male per 100 females)",     y = "Density"   ) +   theme_bw()

previous_headings: Example 3: Sex ratio in Seoul Metropolitan Area
title: Regional analysis with tidycensuskr
text: Within Seoul Metropolitan Area, central city districts (Seoul) show higher proportion females, whereas outer suburban areas tend show male-dominated populations. highlights spatial differences gender distribution across metropolitan region.
code: # Load boundaries sf_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020)  # Merge SMA population data with boundaries sf_2020_sma <- sf_2020 |>   inner_join(df_sma, by = "adm2_code")  # Choropleth map for sex ratio ggplot(sf_2020_sma) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = sex_ratio), color = "gray", size = 0.01) +   scale_fill_gradient2(     low = "#2C7BB6", mid = "white", high = "#D7191C",     midpoint = 100,                        # 100 = equal male/female     name = "Sex ratio\n(males per 100 females)"   ) +   labs(title = "Sex ratio in the Seoul Metropolitan Area (2020)") +   theme_void()

previous_headings: Example 1: Spatial autocorrelation of economic activity in South Korea
title: Analytics Gallery with tidycensuskr
text: example, use Moran’s statistics analyze spatial distribution economic activity (measured number registered companies) across South Korea 2020. Global Moran’s evaluates whether overall spatial autocorrelation, .e., whether areas similar company counts tend cluster together nationwide. High-High (H-H): districts high values surrounded high-value districts. Low-Low (L-L): districts low values surrounded low-value districts. High-Low (H-L): potential spatial outliers high values surrounded low-value neighbors. Low-High (L-H): potential spatial outliers low values surrounded high-value neighbors. resulting LISA cluster map highlights economic activities concentrated sparse relative neighboring areas.

previous_headings: Example 1: Spatial autocorrelation of economic activity in South Korea
title: Analytics Gallery with tidycensuskr
code: # Load 2020 boundaries sf_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020)  # Load 2020 economy data df_2020_economy <- anycensus(year = 2020,                               type = "economy")  # Merge with spatial data sf_2020_economy <- sf_2020 |>   inner_join(df_2020_economy, by = "adm2_code")   # Variable of interest: number of companies var <- sf_2020_economy$company_total_cnt

previous_headings: Example 1: Spatial autocorrelation of economic activity in South Korea
title: Analytics Gallery with tidycensuskr
code: # Build neighbors (queen contiguity) and spatial weights nb <- poly2nb(sf_2020_economy, queen = TRUE) lw <- nb2listw(nb, style = "W", zero.policy = TRUE)  # Global Moran's I test global_moran <- moran.test(var, lw, zero.policy = TRUE) global_moran ##  ##  Moran I test under randomisation ##  ## data:  var   ## weights: lw   ## n reduced by no-neighbour observations   ##  ## Moran I statistic standard deviate = 10.35, p-value < 2.2e-16 ## alternative hypothesis: greater ## sample estimates: ## Moran I statistic       Expectation          Variance  ##       0.424571643      -0.004149378       0.001715960

previous_headings: Example 1: Spatial autocorrelation of economic activity in South Korea
what: Local Moran’s I and LISA map
title: Analytics Gallery with tidycensuskr
text: results reveal strong metropolitan concentration economic activity. High-High (H-H) clusters predominantly located Seoul Metropolitan Area, reflecting central role South Korea’s economy. Low-Low (L-L) clusters appear Gangwon Province along borders Jeollabuk-, Jeollanam-, Gyeongsangbuk-, Chungcheongnam-, indicating regions consistently low levels company presence. spatial pattern highlights dominance capital region economic activity relative sparsity industrial business units peripheral provinces.
code: # Local Moran's I local_moran <- localmoran(var, lw, zero.policy = TRUE)  # Bind results back to sf object sf_2020_economy <- sf_2020_economy |>   mutate(     Ii   = local_moran[, "Ii"],     pval = local_moran[, "Pr(z != E(Ii))"]   )  mean_var <- mean(var, na.rm = TRUE)  sf_2020_economy <- sf_2020_economy |>   mutate(     cluster = case_when(       var > mean_var & Ii > 0 & pval <= 0.05 ~ "High-High",       var < mean_var & Ii > 0 & pval <= 0.05 ~ "Low-Low",       var > mean_var & Ii < 0 & pval <= 0.05 ~ "High-Low",       var < mean_var & Ii < 0 & pval <= 0.05 ~ "Low-High",       TRUE ~ "Not significant"     )   )  ggplot(sf_2020_economy) +   geom_sf(aes(fill = cluster), color = "grey70", size = 0.05) +   scale_fill_manual(     values = c(       "High-High"     = "red",       "Low-Low"       = "blue",       "High-Low"      = "pink",       "Low-High"      = "lightblue",       "Not significant" = "white"     )   ) +   labs(title = "LISA Cluster Map of Company units (2020)") +   theme_minimal()

what: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
title: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
text: District boundaries censal years tidycensuskr package package companion package tidycensuskr. provides district boundaries censal years South Korea.

title: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
text: --date version can installed GitHub :
code: install.packages("tidycensussfkr", repos = "https://sigmafelix.r-universe.dev") # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("sigmafelix/tidycensussfkr")

title: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
text: load_districts() function main function load district boundaries censal years. current version supports three censal years: 2010, 2015, 2020. function takes single argument year specifies censal year load. default value 2020.
code: library(tidycensussfkr) #> tidycensussfkr 0.1.0 (2025-10-01) library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.12.2, GDAL 3.11.3, PROJ 9.4.1; sf_use_s2() is TRUE sf::sf_use_s2(FALSE) #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off  # Load 2020 district boundaries adm2_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020) head(adm2_2020) #> Simple feature collection with 6 features and 2 fields #> Geometry type: POLYGON #> Dimension:     XY #> Bounding box:  xmin: 1136287 ymin: 1673842 xmax: 1148948 ymax: 1690481 #> Projected CRS: KGD2002 / Unified CS #>   year adm2_code                       geometry #> 1 2020     21140 POLYGON ((1147104 1689056, ... #> 2 2020     21020 POLYGON ((1137763 1683521, ... #> 3 2020     21010 POLYGON ((1139121 1678921, ... #> 4 2020     21040 POLYGON ((1144618 1676795, ... #> 5 2020     21070 POLYGON ((1142639 1682655, ... #> 6 2020     21130 POLYGON ((1147030 1688822, ... plot(st_geometry(adm2_2020))

title: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
text: district boundaries sourced Statistics Korea (KOSTAT) website. original data simplified reduce file size improve visualization performance. simplification process may resulted loss detail boundaries.

title: District Boundaries by Censal Years for tidycensuskr Package
text: Please report issues, bugs, suggestions Issues page GitHub repository.

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
text: Load sf district polygons

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
code: load_districts(year = 2020)

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
text: year integer(1). census year load. Defaults 2020.

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
text: sf object containing district polygons.

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
text: function loads district polygons specified year package's extdata directory. polygons stored RDS file read using readRDS function. polygons Simple Features (sf) format, suitable spatial data analysis R. polygons include following attributes: year: census year (e.g., 2020). adm2_code: administrative code district.

title: Load sf district polygons — load_districts
code: library(sf) #> Linking to GEOS 3.12.1, GDAL 3.8.4, PROJ 9.4.0; sf_use_s2() is TRUE sf_use_s2(FALSE) #> Spherical geometry (s2) switched off sf_2020 <- load_districts(year = 2020)
